awd_titl_txt: GOALI: Collaborative Research: On-Demand Continuous-Flow Production of High Performance Acrylic Resins: from Electronic-Level Modeling to Modular Process Intensification
awd_abstract_narration:
The proposed collaborative research project between two academic groups and an industrial partner, Axalta Coating Systems (formerly DuPont Performance Coatings), aims to investigate the effects of molecular oxygen on free-radical polymerization (FRP). The effects of molecular oxygen can be either catalytic, at high temperatures, or inhibitory, at low temperatures. The majority of FRP studies with molecular oxygen have focused on its inhibitory effects, so it will be of great fundamental interest to discover the mechanisms of oxygen-based catalysis under different reaction conditions. To translate this finding into practical industrial processes, it is vital to understand how the concentration of molecular oxygen influences reaction rates and resulting polymer conversion and microstructure.

The team proposes to: (a) Identify the most likely mechanisms for polymer-chain initiation by molecular oxygen and the departure of oxygen from live polymer chains before they are terminated, using Density Functional Theory (DFT); (b) Design and conduct batch polymerization experiments to capture the initiating and product species and to verify the theoretically-predicted species and mechanisms; (c) Develop a macroscopic mechanistic model of an oxygen-initiated polymerization tubular reactor (PTR) to perform model-based design; and (d) Develop a modular PTR design that intensifies and modularizes acrylic resin processes. The reduction or elimination of conventional thermal initiators (normally the most expensive component of a resin) will lower the operating costs. The elimination of residual groups left by conventional initiators in the final product (which adversely affect polymer properties such as UV resistance) and the optimal operation of FRP reactors will improve the resin quality. Beyond acrylates, the outcomes of this research may impact every free-radical polymerization process. In addition to training two graduate students, the team plans to create computer modeling modules and projects to provide research training opportunities to undergraduates selected from underrepresented groups through Drexel's Co-op program and UPenn's Vagelos Integrated Program in Energy Research (VIPER).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Polymer resins and coatings are widely used in many applications including construction, cars and trucks, planes and ships, decorative accessories, laminates, flooring, linings, surface coatings, structural and decorative panels, adhesives, elastomers, signs, and translucent tiles. As resins and coatings composed of low molecular-weight polymer chains have adequately low viscosity even at high polymer concentrations, they require a low level of solvents to be sprayable/brushable. Thus, when the solvents are organic, the application of these resins and coatings is accompanied by the release of low amounts of organic solvents; these resins and coatings are environmentally friendly. Free-radical polymerization reactors are typically operated at higher temperatures to produce these low molecular weight polymer chains. At these elevated temperatures, scission reactions were known to contribute significantly to the reduction of the molecular weights. This and previous projects of ours discovered other reactions that lower the molecular weights, thus positively contributing to the production of environmentally friendly polymer resins and coatings. In our previous project, we discovered theoretically and experimentally and reported the occurrence of self-initiation of alkyl acrylates at high temperatures (> 140 °C).

 

In this project, we discovered that molecular oxygen, available in air for free, considerably promotes the formation of free radicals in the presence of alkyl acrylates at elevated temperatures, without being consumed. This discovery indicates that the concentration of molecular oxygen in the reaction media can be used a knob to control the rate of the free-radical polymerization, and that free-radical polymerization can be carried out to completion without using any added conventional thermal initiators. As thermal initiators are normally the most expensive component of resin/coating formulations, an immediate consequence of this reduction or elimination of conventional thermal initiators is considerable cost savings. Our combined computational quantum mechanics, macroscopic-scale modeling, and laboratory experiments allowed us to gain fundamental insights into the reaction mechanisms through which molecular oxygen contributes to the polymerization.

 

The knowledge gained in this work allows for the rational design of new polymerization processes to produce high quality, environmentally friendly, solvent-borne paints and coatings at lower operation costs. It will also impact every free-radical polymerization process. The knowledge offers significant economic benefits, including reducing the cost and increasing the quality of acrylate polymers by eliminating the need for extrinsic initiators, thus boosting the U.S. economy.

 

This project had a significant impact on scientific workforce development. 2 postdoctoral research associates, and 4 Ph.D. and 6 (4 female) undergraduate students were trained in this project under the joint mentorship of the senior investigators at Drexel University, the University of Pennsylvania, and Axalta Coating Systems. This unique environment gave these students an understanding of academic science, academic engineering, and corporate research strengths, constraints, and demands. Two of the Ph.D. students, Ahmad Arabi Shamsabadi and Hossein Riazi, graduated and joined Pall Corporation, NY and Evonik Industries, PA, respectively.


Last Modified: 12/21/2022
Modified by: Masoud Soroush
